title: 113_s274
content: The "Children Eating Well Act" or the "CHEW Act" is the short title of the legislation. It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The "Children Eating Well Act" defines terms such as elementary school, local educational agency, secondary school, and State educational agency according to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It also defines "programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education" as initiatives that enhance students' ability to choose healthy foods and make informed eating decisions. The "Children Eating Well Act" aims to promote healthy eating habits among students by providing education on choosing and consuming healthy foods, considering various influences on eating habits, and using scientifically sound nutritional materials based on the Dietary Guidelines for Americans. The "Children Eating Well Act" promotes healthy eating habits through education using scientifically sound nutritional materials based on the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, and includes professional development programs for teachers and school staff to teach healthy eating effectively. The "Children Eating Well Act" includes programs to promote healthy eating and nutrition education. Local educational agencies receiving assistance under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 must develop and implement programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools, including integrating these programs throughout the school day and using educational materials to emphasize these concepts. The programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools include integrating these concepts throughout the school day and using educational materials to emphasize knowledge of healthy foods, a balanced diet, and the integration of healthy eating with physical activity. The local educational agency must promote a balanced approach to healthy eating and lifestyle, integrate healthy eating with physical activity, and provide various wellness activities to improve student knowledge without focusing on weight loss. Schools' efforts in improving nutrition understanding among students should be periodically monitored. The local educational agency must promote a balanced approach to healthy eating and lifestyle, integrate healthy eating with physical activity, and provide wellness activities to improve student knowledge without focusing on weight loss. Schools' efforts in improving nutrition understanding among students should be periodically monitored, consulting with various stakeholders and organizations with nutrition education expertise. The local educational agency must collaborate with organizations with nutrition education expertise to develop programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education. This includes working with government authorities like Team Nutrition of the Food and Nutrition Service for guidance and assistance in implementing and evaluating such programs. The local educational agency collaborates with nutrition education organizations, government authorities like Team Nutrition, and school wellness councils to develop, implement, and evaluate programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools. The local educational agency collaborates with nutrition education organizations, government authorities, and school wellness councils to design programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education in schools. This includes integrating programs with the school wellness policy and providing professional development on nutrition education to staff members. Each State educational agency must meet these requirements. The Russell National School Lunch Act requires State educational agencies to report on programs promoting healthy eating and nutrition education. An inter-agency task force will be established to review nutrition education efforts. The Russell National School Lunch Act mandates State educational agencies to report on promoting healthy eating and nutrition education. An inter-agency task force, consisting of the Secretaries of Education, Agriculture, and Health and Human Services, will review nutrition education curricula and recommend effective programs for schools. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
